prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my girlfriend she doesn’t need to make plans every time I want to game?
My girlfriend and I have been living together for 4 months now. We’ve been together for 3 years, and I’ve loved every minute of it and we absolutely adore each other.

When we first got together I gave up a lot of my free time for dates and other couple things like that. 

We would spend the night together sometimes. But when we would go home alone, to our respective houses. I would use that time to get my game time in.

Now flash forward, we live together and are obviously spending more time together. 

It all started a few weeks ago after work, when my buddy messaged me and asked me to get on and play Apex Legends, I say yeah, and tell my girlfriend I’m gonna play some games if she doesn’t mind. Up until that point we only used my Xbox as an entertainment system ( think Hulu, YouTube and Netflix.) 

I had previously taken a pretty long break from games and I didn’t expect this to be her reaction.

She said, it’s not fair for me to play games because she has nothing else to do while we play. I said, well you can watch me play jokingly, I thought she was kidding at first, but then she continued and said if I wanna make plans then to let her know so she can be busy while I’m busy. She also said she missed me. I told her we could have time for just us when I was done playing, and that it wasn’t a “plan.” I’m not going anywhere, I’ll be right here. I even told her we could talk while I played. But she didn’t want to have any of it. She just went to her sisters house for a few hours, and I proceeded to get some dubs.

Then, it became an argument we had 2-3 times. I even gave her advanced notice on an occasion or two but If she failed to make her plan she blamed it on me. So I told her ‘she didn’t need to go out every time, I’m busy. Just relax and chill on your phone or use my laptop.’ 

She’s the kinda girl who wants constant attention and I am fine with that, but I also want to chill with my friends online and play. 

AITA?

Tl;dr Girlfriend wants me to preplan my gaming time so she can make plans to go out. I said she doesn’t need to go out just because I wanna play games.
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

The author and his girlfriend have been together three years and live together now. The issue started when he wanted to play Apex Legends with a friend. He told her he was going to play, and she got upset because she felt she had nothing to do while he was gaming. The author thought she was joking when he suggested she watch him play, but she took it seriously. She ended up going to her sister's house for a few hours. This led to repeated arguments where she expected him to plan his gaming so she could make her own plans. He told her she didn't need to go out, just relax or use her phone/laptop. He says she wants constant attention but he also wants his game time.

Hmm. So the key points here are communication and expectations. When they started living together, their schedules are overlapping more. The author had previously given up a lot of his free time for dates, but now he wants his own time. The girlfriend feels neglected when he's gaming because she's not doing anything else. The author is defensive, thinking she should just chill or use her phone instead of making plans. 

The girlfriend's reaction seems valid because she's living with him and might expect some independence but also some shared time. The author's initial reaction was to dismiss her feelings by suggesting she watch him play, which wasn't taken well. Then, when she went to her sister's, he played games, which could come off as dismissive. 

The argument arises because the girlfriend wants pre-planning so she can have her own time, which is reasonable. The author, on the other hand, doesn't see why she needs to make plans just because he's gaming. But when you live together, having separate activities can be tricky. The author might not be considering her need for personal time as much as his own. 

Is the author in the wrong? Well, he's not wrong for wanting his own time. But he might not be wrong either. However, the way he's handling it could be part of the problem. By not acknowledging her feelings and suggesting she just relax or use her phone, he might be invalidating her need for her own space. Maybe they need to find a middle ground where they both have time for themselves but also respect each other's needs. 

The girlfriend's expectation that he should plan his gaming so she can make plans might be a bit much if he's just having casual game sessions. But her feeling neglected is real. The author's response of "she doesn't need to go out" is dismissive. Maybe he should be more open to communicating and finding a balance. 

In relationships, it's about mutual respect and understanding. The author isn't entirely wrong for wanting his hobbies, but he might be in the wrong for not considering her feelings and not finding a compromise. The girlfriend's needs for attention and personal time are valid. So perhaps the author is partially in the wrong. 

But the question is whether he is in the wrong. The options are A (yes) or B (no). Considering all that, I think the answer might be A because he's not considering her feelings adequately and is dismissive. However, some might argue B because he has a right to his hobbies. But given the context of their living together and her needing attention, the answer is likely A. Wait, but maybe not. Let me check again. 

The author's actions stem from wanting his own time, which is reasonable. However, his response to her feelings was dismissive. He could have been more empathetic. So maybe it's a shared fault, but the question is whether he is in the wrong. Since he's the one who's causing the conflict by not addressing her feelings, maybe A is correct. So I'll go with A.
